title: Riverdance celebrates 20 years at Calgary's Jubilee Auditorium
text:
In its many incarnations and versions, the dance spectacular Riverdance has been thrilling audiences around the world for two decades. 

Riverdance 20 Years is working its magic on Calgary audiences at the Jubilee until Oct. 11 and it had the opening night audience applauding and cheering individual numbers and individual performers culminating in a raucous standing ovation for the curtain call. 
This is a production that uses sound, lighting, costumes and projections to accentuate the always impressive dance numbers. 
Wisely, the show features more than Irish dancing, which thrilling though it may be soon becomes just variations of the same steps in different formations. 
There are several particularly haunting vocal solos from Sarah Woods and Dewitt Fleming Jr. plus some stunning a capella group harmonies. 
When the four musicians who provide all the background music for the dancers take centre stage individually or together they really rock the Jubilee. 
There's a duel between fiddler Pat Mangan and drummer Mark Alfred that is nothing short of amazing and when Matt Bashford does a solo number on the uilleann pipes or Ken Edge on his saxophone it's breathtaking. 
I could have listened to Mangan's fiddle solos all night they are so rich. 
All the male dancers in the Irish troupe are so lithe and the women so willowy yet they all possess so much stamina and unfaltering stamina and enthusiasm. 
With his long legs and slim torso, Jason O'Neill, the male principal dancer, recalls a young Tommy Tune not just in looks but in the flare, confidence and exuberance with which he dances. 
Female principal Ciara Sexton has a pixie look which is used to great visual advantage when she is dancing with O'Neill and her troupe of female Irish dancers. 
Once in both acts, the show takes a detour to Spain to allow Rocio Montoya to dazzle with her flamenco moves which, in the first act, are given a hint of Ireland when she is joined by four Irish male dancers. 
The first act closes with the Riverdance number that made this show famous and it still thrills with is synchronized moves. 
The second act opens with a kind of Irish hoedown number but the real stunner comes when the four male and three female Russian dancers take the spotlight. 
The men seem to defy gravity as their bodies whirl across the stage or leap into the air for splits. 
We've come to expect to see female dancers kick above their heads but to watch the incredibly limber Rifat Gaddulkhakov, Alexander Safonov and Eugeniu Turcan do the same is truly breathtaking. 
There is a very clever number in the second act featuring O'Neill and two accompanying male Irish dancer sparring with tap dancers JL Williams and Andrew Prashad. 
It's played for great welcomed comic effect but that doesn't in anyway diminish what these men are capable of executing. 
It's not just the talent on display in Riverdance 20 Years but the way director John Mccolgan showcases it that makes the show such a rewarding and memorable experience. 
There are performances at the Jubilee Oct. 10 at 8 p.m. and Oct. 11 at 2 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. Sponsored Links
